trans-unit.source: Click here to change column calculation.
trans-unit.target: Click here to change column calculation.

trans-unit.source: Click here to change column content.
trans-unit.target: Click here to change column content.

trans-unit.source: Listboxes contain "headers" and "footers". The headers are mandatory numerical variables used to determine the sort order. The footers can hold any type of variable. The values of these variables can be automatically calculated by 4D (Min, Max, Average, etc.). This can be set up for each footer using the form editor or by programming.
trans-unit.target: Listboxes contain "headers" and "footers". The headers are mandatory numerical variables used to determine the sort order. The footers can hold any type of variable. The values of these variables can be automatically calculated by 4D (Min, Max, Average, etc.). This can be set up for each footer using the form editor or by programming.

trans-unit.source: Hierachical listboxes must use arrays as data sources. Nevertheless, these arrays can be filled "on the fly" thanks to the events "on expand" and "on collapse" that are generated in the listbox object. The advantage of this technique is to avoid saturating the memory by filling arrays needlessly.
trans-unit.target: Hierachical listboxes must use arrays as data sources. Nevertheless, these arrays can be filled "on the fly" thanks to the events "on expand" and "on collapse" that are generated in the listbox object. The advantage of this technique is to avoid saturating the memory by filling arrays needlessly.

trans-unit.source: Number of rows in the listbox:
trans-unit.target: Number of rows in the listbox:

trans-unit.source: The first columns of the listboxes can be defined as "locked" which means they cannot be scrolled horizontally and are always visible. They also can be set up as "static" which means they cannot be moved or switched any longer with any other columns. In the example above, the colomns are displayed using red characters and locked columns are displayed on a blue background.
trans-unit.target: The first columns of the listboxes can be defined as "locked" which means they cannot be scrolled horizontally and are always visible. They also can be set up as "static" which means they cannot be moved or switched any longer with any other columns. In the example above, the colomns are displayed using red characters and locked columns are displayed on a blue background.

trans-unit.source: One column is static and cannot be moved.
trans-unit.target: One column is static and cannot be moved.

trans-unit.source: <n> columns are static and cannot be moved.
trans-unit.target: <n> columns are static and cannot be moved.

trans-unit.source: One column is locked and cannot be scrolled horizontally.
trans-unit.target: One column is locked and cannot be scrolled horizontally.

trans-unit.source: <n> columns are locked and cannot be scrolled hozizontally.
trans-unit.target: <n> columns are locked and cannot be scrolled hozizontally.

trans-unit.source: List box based on records selection
trans-unit.target: List box based on records selection

trans-unit.source: List box based on entity selection
trans-unit.target: List box based on entity selection

trans-unit.source: Listboxes can contain either arrays (texts, numbers, dates, pictures, etc.) or fields from the tables of the database. In both cases, the values can be enterable or not, depending on the developer's choice. The number of arrays as well as their sizes are limited by the available memory, so, when working with a large amount of data, you should consider using records rather than arrays.
trans-unit.target: Listboxes can contain either arrays (texts, numbers, dates, pictures, etc.) or fields from the tables of the database. In both cases, the values can be enterable or not, depending on the developer's choice. The number of arrays as well as their sizes are limited by the available memory, so, when working with a large amount of data, you should consider using records rather than arrays.

trans-unit.source: When using arrays, they will always be synchronised during sort operations and must contain the same number of rows. If they don't, some of them (the last ones) will not be displayed.
trans-unit.target: When using arrays, they will always be synchronised during sort operations and must contain the same number of rows. If they don't, some of them (the last ones) will not be displayed.

trans-unit.source: When displaying directly a selection of records, the columns may contain formulas: in this example, the 1st column contains the concatenation of three fields belonging to three distinct tables linked together by an automatic relation.
trans-unit.target: When displaying directly a selection of records, the columns may contain formulas: in this example, the 1st column contains the concatenation of three fields belonging to three distinct tables linked together by an automatic relation.

trans-unit.source: The list boxes are objects used to display or modify arrays or records. The graphical appearence of listboxes is highly customizable. Colors, sizes, styles as well as visibility of the objects that belong to it (columns, headers, footers, scrollbars, grid, etc.) can be modified directly in the form editor as well as using programming.
trans-unit.target: The list boxes are objects used to display or modify arrays or records. The graphical appearence of listboxes is highly customizable. Colors, sizes, styles as well as visibility of the objects that belong to it (columns, headers, footers, scrollbars, grid, etc.) can be modified directly in the form editor as well as using programming.

trans-unit.source: The list boxes that contain arrays can have two display modes : synchronized arrays or hierarchical. The hierarchy is based on repetition of values inside the N first arrays. N represents the number of hierachical levels that can be defined in the form editor or by programming.
trans-unit.target: The list boxes that contain arrays can have two display modes : synchronized arrays or hierarchical. The hierarchy is based on repetition of values inside the N first arrays. N represents the number of hierachical levels that can be defined in the form editor or by programming.

trans-unit.source: The height of the rows as well as headers and footers can be set up in "lines" or "pixels" units. Using lines, the height is automatically calculated based on the sizes and fonts used in the objects. Switching from one mode to another, 4D calculates as well as possible the new height in lines or in pixels.
trans-unit.target: The height of the rows as well as headers and footers can be set up in "lines" or "pixels" units. Using lines, the height is automatically calculated based on the sizes and fonts used in the objects. Switching from one mode to another, 4D calculates as well as possible the new height in lines or in pixels.

trans-unit.source: The cells, and by extension the rows, can be set as enterable or not by programming: This is performed during the event "on before data entry" by using the $0 variable. (*) If this variable is set to zero (default value) then the cell is enterable. If it is set to -1, then the cell will not be enterable. (*) This event is generated in the listbox itself as well as in each included and enterable column.
trans-unit.target: The cells, and by extension the rows, can be set as enterable or not by programming: This is performed during the event "on before data entry" by using the $0 variable. (*) If this variable is set to zero (default value) then the cell is enterable. If it is set to -1, then the cell will not be enterable. (*) This event is generated in the listbox itself as well as in each included and enterable column.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, the locking of the rows is based on a boolean array which is read during the event "on before data entry". Locking cells is based on the content of the cells themselves: if a cell is not empty, it is not enterable any longer (this example is of course arbitrary!)
trans-unit.target: In the example above, the locking of the rows is based on a boolean array which is read during the event "on before data entry". Locking cells is based on the content of the cells themselves: if a cell is not empty, it is not enterable any longer (this example is of course arbitrary!)

trans-unit.source: Choice lists can be associated with columns. These associations can be defined directly in Design mode in the form editor or, afterwards, by programming. This might be very useful according to the different contexts of use of the same listbox. When the listbox contains arrays, a specific command allows you to insert or delete one or more rows at once, which avoids having to do so individually in each displayed array.
trans-unit.target: Choice lists can be associated with columns. These associations can be defined directly in Design mode in the form editor or, afterwards, by programming. This might be very useful according to the different contexts of use of the same listbox. When the listbox contains arrays, a specific command allows you to insert or delete one or more rows at once, which avoids having to do so individually in each displayed array.

trans-unit.source: The columns that hold text arrays or text fields can, optionally, be set up as multi-styled. This option allows you to display contents with distinct colors, sizes, and font famillies.
trans-unit.target: The columns that hold text arrays or text fields can, optionally, be set up as multi-styled. This option allows you to display contents with distinct colors, sizes, and font famillies.

trans-unit.source: Collection type list boxes can contain scalar elements (text, numeric, etc.) or objects.
trans-unit.target: Collection type list boxes can contain scalar elements (text, numeric, etc.) or objects.

trans-unit.source: The entity selection list boxes display the attributes of each entity. The content of the columns can also be the result of an expression.
trans-unit.target: The entity selection list boxes display the attributes of each entity. The content of the columns can also be the result of an expression.
